t: Jeremiah 4
Judah Threatened with Invasion
“If*pn you will return, O Israel,” declares the Lord,*s “Then*iln you should return to Me. And*ln if you will put away your detested things from My presence, And*ln will not waver,
And*ln you will swear, ‘As the Lord*s lives,’ In*ln truth, in justice and in righteousness; Then*ln the nations will bless themselves in Him, And*ln in Him they will glory.”
For*p thus says the Lord*s to the men of Judah and to Jerusalem, “Break*pn up your fallow ground, And*ln do not sow among thorns.

Circumcise*ln yourselves to the Lord*s And*ln remove the foreskins of your heart, Men*ln of Judah and inhabitants of Jerusalem, Or*ln else My wrath will go forth like fire And*ln burn with none to quench it, Because*ln of the evil of your deeds.”
Declare*ln in Judah and proclaim in Jerusalem, and say, “Blow*ln the trumpet in the land; Cry*ln aloud and say, ‘Assemble*ln yourselves, and let us go Into*ln the fortified cities.’
Lift*ln up a standard toward Zion! Seek*ln refuge, do not stand still,*i For*ln I am bringing evil from the north, And*ln great destruction.
A*ln lion has gone up from his thicket, And*ln a destroyer of nations has set out; He*ln has gone out from his place To*ln make your land a waste. Your*ln cities will be ruins Without*ln inhabitant.
For*ln this, put on sackcloth, Lament*ln and wail; For*ln the fierce anger of the Lord*s Has*ln not turned back from us.”
“It*p shall come about in that day,” declares the Lord,*s “that the heart of the king and the heart of the princes will fail; and the priests will be appalled and the prophets will be astounded.”
Then*p I said, “Ah, Lord God!*s Surely You have utterly deceived this people and Jerusalem, saying, ‘You will have peace’; whereas a sword touches the throat.”

In*p that time it will be said to this people and to Jerusalem, “A scorching wind from the bare heights in the wilderness in the direction of the daughter of My people—not to winnow and not to cleanse,
a wind too strong for this—will come at My command; now I will also pronounce judgments against them.
Behold,*pn he goes up like clouds, And*ln his chariots like the whirlwind; His*ln horses are swifter than eagles. Woe*ln to us, for we are ruined!”
Wash*ln your heart from evil, O Jerusalem, That*ln you may be saved. How*ln long will your wicked thoughts Lodge*ln within you?
For*ln a voice declares from Dan, And*ln proclaims wickedness from Mount Ephraim.
“Report*ln it*i to the nations, now! Proclaim*ln over Jerusalem, ‘Besiegers*ln come from a far country, And*ln lift their voices against the cities of Judah.
Like*ln watchmen of a field they are against her round about, Because*ln she has rebelled against Me,’ declares the Lord.*s
Your*ln ways and your deeds Have*ln brought these things to you. This*ln is your evil. How bitter! How*ln it has touched your heart!”
Lament over Judah’s Devastation
My*pn soul, my soul! I am in anguish! Oh, my heart! My*ln heart is pounding in me; I*ln cannot be silent, Because*ln you have heard, O my soul, The*ln sound of the trumpet, The*ln alarm of war.
Disaster*ln on disaster is proclaimed, For*ln the whole land is devastated; Suddenly*ln my tents are devastated, My*ln curtains in an instant.
How*ln long must I see the standard And*ln hear the sound of the trumpet?
“For*ln My people are foolish, They*ln know Me not; They*ln are stupid children And*ln have no understanding. They*ln are shrewd to do evil, But*ln to do good they do not know.”
I*ln looked on the earth, and behold, it*i was*i formless and void; And*ln to the heavens, and they had no light.
I*ln looked on the mountains, and behold, they were quaking, And*ln all the hills moved to and fro.
I*ln looked, and behold, there was no man, And*ln all the birds of the heavens had fled.
I*ln looked, and behold, the fruitful land was a wilderness, And*ln all its cities were pulled down Before*ln the Lord,*s before His fierce anger.
For*ln thus says the Lord,*s “The*ln whole land shall be a desolation, Yet*ln I will not execute a complete destruction.
For*ln this the earth shall mourn And*ln the heavens above be dark, Because*ln I have spoken, I have purposed, And*ln I will not change My mind, nor will I turn from it.”
At*ln the sound of the horseman and bowman every city flees; They*ln go into the thickets and climb among the rocks; Every*ln city is forsaken, And*ln no man dwells in them.

And*ln you, O desolate one, what will you do? Although*ln you dress in scarlet, Although*ln you decorate yourself*i with*i ornaments of gold, Although*ln you enlarge your eyes with paint, In*ln vain you make yourself beautiful. Your*iln lovers despise you; They*ln seek your life.

For*ln I heard a cry as of a woman in labor, The*ln anguish as of one giving birth to her first child, The*ln cry of the daughter of Zion gasping for breath, Stretching*ln out her hands, saying,*i “Ah,*ln woe is me, for I faint before murderers.”
